org.jdesktop.swingx.table
Class SeparatedTableModel<_RowType>

java.lang.Object
  javax.swing.table.AbstractTableModel
      org.jdesktop.swingx.table.SeparatedTableModel<_RowType>
Type Parameters:
_RowType - The class used to represent each row of the table. (See assumption 1, below)
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, javax.swing.table.TableModel, BasicRowHeaderModel
public class SeparatedTableModel<_RowType>
extends javax.swing.table.AbstractTableModel
implements BasicRowHeaderModel

This class implements a TableModel by splitting the model into separate row and column models. This solves many common maintainence issues with TableModels, and makes them much easier to work with.

This can't be used with all TableModels, but it can be used with many tables that share a very common structure. It makes two assumptions about the table structure in order to separate the model into a row model and some column models. This class then implements the model's methods by extracting the row and passing it to the specified column. It is then up to the developer to supply the columns by extending the AbstractColumn class, which is very simple.

The assumptions are common to most tables. They are:
1) Each row represents an instance of a the same class.
2) Each column represents a field from that instance, or a value that can be derived from that instance.

If your TableModel meets these two assumptions, you can use this class. Each column in a SeparatedTableModel is a separate class that contains all the information needed to display that column in the table, including information used by the JTable's column headers. The columns are implemented by extending the AbstractColumn class and overriding its getValue() method, and any other methods that are needed. This makes the TableModel much easier to maintain, since any changes to a specific column are made in that column's class, and won't interact with the code for any other column.

Column classes tend to be small. In the example below, they are written as static inner classes of the main TableModel class for convenience, but this is a matter of personal preference.

This example displays some information about people. Each individual is represnted by an instance of class Person, which has getters and setters for the name and birthday fields, and a getter for the "age" property. A SeparatedTableModel might look like this: 

 public class PeopleTableModel extends SeparatedTableModel<Person> {
   PeopleTableModel(Collection<Person> rows) {
     super(rows);
     addColumn(new FirstNameColumn());
     addColumn(new LastNameColumn());
     addColumn(new BirthdayColumn());
     addColumn(new AgeColumn());
   }
 
   private static class FirstNameColumn extends AbstractColumn<Person, String> {
     FirstNameColumn() { super("First Name", String.class, 100); }
     public String getValue(Person row) { return row.getFirstName(); }
     public void setValue(String firstName, Person row) { row.setFirstName(firstName); }
     public Comparable<?> getComparableValue(Person row) { return row.getFirstNameKey(); }
     public boolean isEditable(Person row) { return true; }
   }
 
   private static class LastNameColumn extends AbstractColumn<Person, String> {
     LastNameColumn() { super("Last Name", String.class, 100); }
     public String getValue(Person row) { return row.getLastName(); }
     public void setValue(String lastName, Person row) { row.setLastName(lastName); }
     public Comparable<?> getComparableValue(Person row) { return row.getLastNameKey(); }
     public boolean isEditable(Person row) { return true; }
   }
 
   private static class BirthdayColumn extends AbstractColumn<Person, Date> {
    BirthdayColumn() { super("Birthday", Date.class, 80, new DateRenderer()); }
    public Date getValue(Person row) { return row.getBirthday(); }
    public void setValue(Date value, Person row) { row.setBirthday(value); }
    public boolean isEditable(Person row) { return true; }
   }
 
   private static class AgeColumn extends AbstractColumn<Person, Integer> {
     AgeColumn() { super("Age", Integer.class, 40); }
     public Integer getValue(Person row) { return row.getAge(); }
     public Comparable<?> getComparableValue(Person row) { return row.getBirthday(); }
   }
 }

Note that only the first three columns override the isEditable() method, and that the third column supplies its own renderer. Also note that three of the columns implement getComparableValue(), to return a value that is useful to sort by. For String classes, this is typically an instance of java.text.CollationKey, which lets you ignore case when sorting. Since this class extends AbstractTableModel, all its familiar table events may be fired.

Author:
Miguel Muñoz
See Also:
AbstractColumn, RowModel, TableRowKeyedSorter, Serialized Form

Constructor Detail

SeparatedTableModel

public SeparatedTableModel(java.util.Collection<_RowType> pRows)
Construct a SeparatedTableModel from a Collection of objects of _RowType. Columns will be added later. If pRows is a List, this will just use that List in the model. If pRows is some other type of Collection, this will construct an ArrayList from the elements and use that in the model.

Parameters:
pRows - The Collection

setValueAt

public void setValueAt(java.lang.Object aValue,
                       int rowIndex,
                       int columnIndex)
Sets the value in the cell at columnIndex and rowIndex to aValue. Delegates this work to the column instance.

This also queries the column's updateTable and (if needed) updateRow properties. If either of those returns true, this calls fireTableRowsUpdated() with either the whole table (if updateTable is true) or the current row (if updateRow is true). If updatTable is true, this doesn't bother to query the updateRow property.

Specified by:
setValueAt in interface javax.swing.table.TableModel
Overrides:
setValueAt in class javax.swing.table.AbstractTableModel
Parameters:
aValue - value to assign to cell
rowIndex - row of cell
columnIndex - column of cell
See Also:
AbstractColumn.getUpdateRow(_RowType), AbstractColumn.getUpdateTable(_RowType), AbstractTableModel.fireTableRowsUpdated(int,int)

getColumnClass

public java.lang.Class<?> getColumnClass(int columnIndex)
Returns the most specific superclass for all the cell values in the column. This is used by the JTable to set up a default renderer and editor for the column. Delegates this to the column instance.

isCellEditable

                              int columnIndex)
Returns true if the cell at rowIndex and columnIndex is editable. Otherwise, setValueAt on the cell will not change the value of that cell. Delegates this work to the column instance.

                                                  int columnIndex)

Returns:

setUpHeader

public static void setUpHeader(javax.swing.JTable tbl)
Since this table model includes information handled by the Table Header as well as the JTable, we need to send the information to the JTableHeader. The user should call this method after setting the model on the JTable.

Without this call, this TableModel won't support column widths, column tool tips, or custom renderers and editors.

Parameters:
tbl - The JTable
See Also:
setUpHeader(javax.swing.JTable)
